												I remember when this game was a buy to play title back in 2009 onwards. I also remember when they made the game free to play and that's pretty much when things started to go down I think. It was truly fun, I won't lie, but the lack of income led to the game's downfall. They switched to Facebook which in my opinion ruined the game. Now, we are here, on Steam and as many have mentioned the game is a classic pay to win facebook game which is a great shame.The game itself is okay. If you love horses, like show jumping or simply want to have a fun past time activity it's a good game, and it's free. You can own a horse that you can customize with a big number of different coats and patterns, main and tail colors, etc. You can buy new tack and new gear in the shop or upgrade what you already have to increase your stats. There's a ton of different courses where you can compete in ranked matches, alone, championships and so on. You have a paddock where you can run around and practice, collect small gifts of exp and coins/diamonds. When you level up you can assign points to different stats of your horse. At the end of the day you horse will need to be groomed and you can sit down and create your own courses for others to use. Well, that's pretty much it actually. And it's not as fun as it may seem. Or at least it's not as fun as it used to be. You no longer have dressage, or cross country (it was in the original game). The graphics seem far worse than the old game was (most likely because they put it on facebook). And to top it all off the game is a money sinkhole. You are required to buy a premium account (subscription) + buy diamonds which are necessary for you to upgrade your items to keep up with other people, and to buy items from the shop which will allow you to have a proper amount of action points which are needed to play and which run out ridiculously fast. Not to mention other small perks which cost diamonds. If you want to play this game casually I guess you can, but if you want to be at all competitive or spend more time playing this, you will have to cough up a lot of cash. The worst thing is that it's not worth it, cause the game doesn't seem to be getting any updates to it's gameplay or graphics. You'll get bored really fast. Despite the fact that I am marginally enjoying this game, I cannot really recommend it. At least not to serious players or those who are not extreme horse fans. You have to pay too much simply to play. Having action points (a.k.a. energy) to play is something that only facebook games should have, not proper computer games that you post here on Steam. If you are a hard core horse fan, give it a shot, because it's free. It's a nice little thing to pass the time. Your action points will not even last for anything longer. If not, then look for something else. If you are willing to pay for a sub, go play Star Stable.Update: I counted the amount of time you have to play with your avaiable action points when they are 100% full. It took me between 5 and 8 min to run out of them. Maybe less.

												I played this game a while back when it was first available for download before it moved to Facebook (which I played, too, but quickly abandoned due to its p2w leanings) and now Steam. I would suggest to the developers, though, that they make gaining XP and currency easier, take away the "pay for currency" gimmicks, and instead focus on making money through a meaningful subscription - such as attractive "add ons" for those who do decide to invest in the game in order to help it grow. Maybe, rather than reaching for funds by limiting a players ability to earn currency in-game, they should focus on "premium" aspects that someone would be interested in paying for (possibly like the ability to own multiple horses, etc.) -- I know this game is a bit of a fledgling (again) but there are better ideas out there to help get it off the ground other than pure frustration for the people who are playing it at this point.

												I played this game years ago, before it went to facebook due to funding issues. Back then it had Cross country, Dressage, Agility/Obstacle and Show Jumping. It wasn't free to play. When it went to face book they dumbed it down considerably, to the point that I wouldn't touch it. Now that the history lesson is out of the way...The revision seems solid. It's still missing Dressage (Thank god, that was so boring) and Cross country (Very sad) but it has the Show jumping and obstacle courses. As well as almost all the old horse colorations, even if you can't mix and match your own anymore they still gave us most of the combinations. (I got my old horse back, for instance)The game does take a little skill to master. Horses do lead changes (correctly, might I add) and they jump fluidly. You have to master your aim and allow your horse to line up it's strides for the jump. If you keep adjusting you will lead change and hit it. The game also allows for you to do hard turns, which is as rare in a horse game as correct lead changes or stride-length. You can lengthen or shorten your own stride as well, which is important depending on how close together the jumps are or how wide they are. I'm not used to the skill point and leveling system but I guess it adds incentive, especially if they don't intend to keep the game afloat with vanity items alone. Since they revised the system in october I am finding myself more tempted to play longer and possibly purchase a sub. A player can level up thier items the same way they level thier horse and each peice of clothing or tack has it's own stats so you can mix and match what you think you need. It is possible to get through the game without paying a dime, but it will take some dedication and time. It's good to remember though that support breeds development. Speaking of horses and breeding. There is none of that in this game. You get one horse and only one. I do not know at the time of this review if you can change it with an item so choose your steed with care. And remember to groom it often, (arrowkeys make grooming and hoof cleaning easier) as it will get quite dirty. :PI adore this game and always have, I am very nitpicky about my horse games as well and while simple, RCC is a quality game for what it is attempting to achive. Especially for being almost 10 years old and dug up from the digital grave twice now.

												Good stuff:You can customize your horse and rider with lots of differently colored items (lots of colors, not lots of items).You can race against other people on horses.It makes a nice plinking noise when you successfully jump over an obstacle.If you are tired and bored of more interesting games, you might enjoy wasting a few minutes playing this.You can get rid of your extra money to spend a few more minutes playing.Grooming your horse is sort of interesting the first few times.  It closes really fast.It doesn't have overly intrusive ads (as in ads that interrupt you while you are riding).It is free to install, run and play, if you are willing to wait to regain energy.I haven't seen any spelling errors.I haven't experienced any crashes.It encourages the use of math by enticing one to calculate how long it takes refill the energy bar.It encourages you to go ride a real horse rather than sit and wait for an hour to ride a fake horse for five minutes.I could go on, there is just so much great stuff about this game!Bad stuff (the main two for me):First, the energy/aciton point depletion rate.  You have an initial maximum of 100 points, which are consumed at a rate of 4 points per jump and 1 point every few seconds of running or standing within the paddock (even while paused).  These points are restored while resting (on the main menu) at a rate of 1 point every 35 seconds, which works out to 100 points in an hour.  This means you can play for about 5-10 minutes every hour.In fairness, you can upgrade certain clothing items to offset this, increasing the rate of recharge to 1 point every 17ish seconds and a max of 200 points.  But the amount of currency to upgrade the items needed is ridculous.Second, the currency rewards are pitiful.  There are two kinds of courses, jumping and agility.  Either way, if you knock stuff over, you incure penalties.  Once you complete the course, you receive 100 coins, 5 diamonds and 100 xp (after gaining 9 levels, these rates have remained unchanged).These rewards are unaffected by how well you ran the course, which means you could knock everything over and still get the maximum reward.To put these numbers in perspective, an apple that restores 100 energy costs 400 diamonds.The most basic of the upgrades mentioned above costs 5000 coins and 500 diamonds.To get this much currency, you would have to run 50 courses.In the end, to play this game, you will either be paying lots of money or spending a lot of time waiting to recharge your horse so you can grind your way through a few minutes of play.

												I stumbled upon this game while attempting to find horse vore porn and was initially very upset and flacid, but when I started actually playing, I realised this was the best game I have ever encountered.Let's start with the gameplay. You get to ride around as a horse with the spacebar and arrow key, and let me tell you when I say it takes skill to beat all the middle-aged women playing this game via facebook. Sometimes I almost have to concentrate on the game instead of staring intently at the horse and wondering if my fantasies will ever come true.But more importantly, the in-depth story. You are a new rider who's trying to make it in the horse-riding scene. The plot only gets deeper when you realise that if you fail to become to number one rider in the world, you too will become a single middle-aged woman who plays this game in her spare time when not looking for dates on match.com so she can actually have children before her biological clock runs out. It really adds pressure to the game.Overall, this game has wit and charm, and I would recommend it to anyone who doesn't want to feel alive anymore, and is waiting for the slow embrace of death to take them away.9/10
